awd_titl_txt: Effect of Low Concentrations of Arsenic on Microbial Iron Reduction
awd_abstract_narration: In natural environments, arsenite (As(III)) is not only more mobile but is also more toxic than arsenate (As(V)) or organoarsenic compounds. Despite a wealth of knowledge gained in the laboratory or aquatic systems displaying remarkably high concentrations of arsenic, little research has been conducted on the effects of low arsenic inputs to natural aquatic systems. Incubations with sediments from a Georgia river revealed that low (< 10 micro M) but increasing As(V) concentrations spurred increases in microbial iron reduction rates accompanied by the secondary recrystallization of Fe oxides. In this project, the mechanism by which low concentrations of arsenic affect anaerobic respiration on Fe oxides by iron-reducing bacteria will be determined. It is hypothesized that As(V) stimulates the energy generation process in iron-reducing bacteria by substitution of phosphate by arsenate during phosphorylation of ADP. This effect is postulated to result from the expression of phosphate transporters and their regulators by iron-reducing bacteria in phosphate-limiting conditions. Finally, the large impact of submicromolar As(V) concentrations on microbial Fe reduction in natural environments is hypothesized to result from a catalytic cycle whereby As(III) produced by microbial detoxification is rapidly recycled to As(V) via chemical oxidation by Mn(IV) oxides present ubiquitously in natural environments. A series of incubations with pure cultures of metal-reducing Shewanella was designed to investigate in a well-controlled biological system the main molecular and geochemical processes affected by small As(V) concentrations using state-of-the art analytical and molecular techniques. This study will simultaneously provide new information on Shewanella and a model for what may occur in natural environments. This work will also provide novel information on the genes and gene products affected by the addition of low concentrations of As(V) in iron-reducing bacteria. While the influence of mineral oxides on trace metal speciation in aquatic systems is well known, the effect of trace metal concentrations on the transformation of mineral oxides is not well recognized. This work will provide the first evidence that Fe respiration is enhanced by a toxic compound and that the structure and reactivity of Fe oxides is affected by these processes. As Fe oxides play a fundamental role as scavengers of contaminants, this work will have ramifications on the fate of other contaminants in aquaticsystems. Metalloids are among the most toxic inorganic pollutants in aquatic systems but, surprisingly, their presence in water reservoirs receives little attention as their concentration is generally low. This study will demonstrate that even low concentrations of a toxic metal affect these ecosystems by altering biological and geochemical processes.

por.por_cntn:
n natural environments, arsenite (As(III)) is not only more mobile but is also more toxic than arsenate (As(V)) or organoarsenic compounds. Despite a wealth of knowledge gained in the laboratory or aquatic systems displaying remarkably high concentrations of arsenic, little research has been conducted on the effects of low arsenic inputs to natural aquatic systems. Incubations with pristine riverine sediments revealed that low but increasing As(V) concentrations spurred increases in microbial iron reduction rates accompanied by the secondary recrystallization of Fe oxides. In this project, we proposed to determine by what mechanism low concentrations of arsenic may affect anaerobic respiration on Fe oxides by iron-reducing bacteria using Shewanella species, as model metal-reducing microorganism. We demonstrated that exposure to increasing As(V) concentrations increases respiration rates on nitrate as well as manganese and iron oxides as terminal electron acceptors only when phosphate is limited in the medium, suggesting that As(V) may be mistakenly incorporated into the cells by their phosphate transport systems. Deletion of the phosphate transport system activated in low environmental phosphate conditions affected respiration capabilities of the organism such that it was not possible to discern the effect of As(V) on cell respiration capabilities. S. oneidensis strain MR-1 was much more severely affected by As(V) than S. putrefaciens strain 200 which respired faster on iron oxides in the presence of high As(V) concentrations. In turn, the extent of ferrihydrite respiration by S. oneidensis strain MR-1 increased significantly at the highest As(V) relative to that of 200 which remained constant regardless of the As(V) concentration. These findings suggest that MR-1 may have developed a resistance mechanism to As(V) which tolerates relatively high As(V) levels. Shewanella species include the arsenate reductase genetic system (ars), which reduces As(V) and senses and exports As(III) out of the cell, and a variety of methylation proteins encoded by the arsM gene which catalyzes the step-wise methylation of As(III) with S-adenosyl-L-methionine (SAM) as methyl donor to produce mono- (MMA), di- (DMA), tri- (TMA), and tetra-methylarsenical species in many microorganisms. Although As(III) was the main product of the detoxification of As(V), the intermediate production of MMA was evidenced in S. oneidensis incubations, and mass balance indicated that other non-detectable arsenic species were formed at steady-state. These findings suggest that methylation is involved in arsenic detoxification mechanism of S. oneidensis. Eighty three methyltransferases (MTases) involved in the SAM-dependent methylation of arsenic were identified in the genome of S. oneidensis, and 27 displayed substrate specificity and amino acid length of potential arsenic methyltransferases. Only 5 of these MTases conferred As(III) resistance to E. coli AW3110 assays with and without dissolved oxygen. Expression of MTases in the heterologous host indicate that different MTase are expressed depending on the chemical composition of the arsenic toxin and suggest that metabolic energy may have to be generated to compensate for the activation of these detoxification pathways. The role of the SAM-dependent arsenic methyltransferases on arsenic detoxification in S. oneidensis MR-1 has yet to be elucidated. Finally, the impact of small As(V) concentrations on anaerobic respiration processes in natural environments may only result from a catalytic cycle whereby As(III) produced by microbial detoxification is rapidly recycled to As(V) via chemical oxidation. Although Mn(IV) oxides represent the best abiotic oxidant of As(III), rates of As(III) oxidation by manganese oxides reported in the literature vary greatly, and reaction mechanisms are under debate. A comprehensive kinetic study of the oxidation of As(III) by birnessite was conducted over a range of pH to determine the appropriate rate law, its rate constant, and the mechanism of the reaction. 

This study will have a significant broader impact: (i) it provides a universal rate law that will be used by geochemists interested in modeling the fate of As(III) oxidation by manganese oxides in natural environments; (ii) more importantly, it improves our understanding of Shewanella detoxification pathways and provides a model for what may occur in natural environments; (iii) it also generates novel information on the genes and gene products affected by the addition of low concentrations of As(V) in iron-reducing bacteria; and (iv) it provides the first evidence that manganese and iron respiration are affected by a toxic compound in low concentration. As Fe(III) oxides are great scavengers of contaminants, this work will have ramifications on the fate of other contaminants in aquatic systems. This project also had a significant educational impact. Two graduate students, one postdoctoral fellow, one research scientist, and one REU student have been trained to combine their expertise in molecular biology, geochemistry, and analytical chemistry to tackle a complex biogeochemical problem. These students and postdocs not only improved their technical skills in two complementary disciplines, they also learned how to communicate across these disciplines. Such skills are needed to improve our understanding of the role of trace metals on microbial processes in the environment.
